guide.name: Guide
guide.description: Select a section (Scoping, for example) and then a topic to see * a brief explanation with links into the full documentation, * shortcuts into Channels, * follow-up topics.

step.description:
Planners use Channels to capture how organizations share or ought to share information to jointly and successfully prevent, respond to, or recover from events that test their missions.
Channels continuously examines these ''information sharing plans'' for gaps and brittleness, and suggests options for remediation.
Channels produces visualizations, analytics and reports that help planners and stakeholders understand and improve complex plans.
Channels computes the personalized information sharing protocols implied in a plan and serves them to its participants.

A plan is the combination of # a model of how information is to be acquired and shared so that tasks that achieve organizational goals can be successfully carried out # an environment that identifies the plan's participants, namely, people and systems in roles of responsibility within organizations A model is applied to an environment to produce visualizations, analytics, diagnostics, reports and information sharing protocols.

An event is a transient change in the world that introduces risks and/or opportunities.
Risks and events should not be confused; an event can introduce risks to one organization while creating opportunities for another.
From the point of view of the plan, an event is an ''incident'' if its occurrence is not caused by the execution of a task in the plan (an 'outside' event).

A phase is a named time period relative to the occurrence of events. A phase is either the time before, during or after events.
A plan can elect to address only the before, during or after of events, or a combination thereof.
The term ''scenario'' is used in information sharing planning to mean one phase of one event, possibly in the context of other past or current events.
A goal is either a risk to, or an opportunity for, an organization that is introduced by the onset or conclusion of an event. Goals are achieved by carrying out tasks, or when an event terminates.

Plans are composed of one or more or more segments. Each segment addresses a list of organizational goals for one scenario.
No two segments should address identical goals in identical scenarios.

Information is what is to be shared by agents (people or systems) via communication channels. Information is named named and is possibly described by a list of essential elements.
An element of information also has a name and may be accompanied by handling instructions and with a secrecy classification.
A task is an action or decision to be taken, individually or as a team, by assigned agents (people or systems) in order to achieve goals and/or acquire information to share.
Specification of information needed to execute a task, plus requirements on its delivery.
Specification of information acquired by or for the execution of a task, plus how it could be (further) shared.
Or flow, for short. How agents carrying out a task that ''produces'' information would commit to share that information with agents carrying out a task that ''consumes'' it.
The list of agents assigned to a task because their profiles match the definition of the task.
The commitment by one agent to share information acquired doing a task with another agent who needs it to successfully do some other task.

A problem with the plan that is either detected automatically by Channels or, upon review, by planners. An issue is either one of * validity (something is inherently wrong in the plan) * completeness (something is obviously missing from the plan) * robustness (something is making the plan likely to fail)
Name the '''events''' within the scope of the plan and identify those that are ''incidents'' – <small>events that are not caused by planned tasks.</small> –
Note that events can also be named anywhere they are used to define another plan element. When they are, they are automatically added to the scope of the plan.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]
Name the '''phases''' within the scope of the plan. Channels will now expect to see at least one segment for each combination of phase and event in scope. The list is part of the plan's ''details''.

script.action: Edit list of phases in scope

step.description: For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]
Name all the (actual) '''organizations''' in scope and indicate which ones are expected to participate – <small>that is, those who are expected to have agents assigned to tasks</small>. – .

script.action: Edit the list of participating organizations

step.description: For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]
Specify the information sharing commitments between organizations that the plan is required to generate.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]
From the top action menu, add new segment, then name it and identify the ''scenario' it addresses –<small>the phase of one event, possibly in the context of past or current events</small>.–
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]

Define a small number of goals the segment is meant to address. For each goal * set the type of goal, * the organization, type or actual, whose goal it is, * the severity/importance of the risk to be mitigated or gain to be achieved. Naming the goal is optional.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]
Define a secrecy classification system to be used in setting * an agent's clearances, * the security of a transmission medium, * the classification level of shared elements of information.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]

Associate a user with one or more agents and add contact information specific to the user's participation as that agent.
Note that users that self-associate with agents that have been defined as "open participation".
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]

Add new task to a segment by clicking ''ADD'' in the Task panel or by selecting ''add new task'' from the top Actions menu. The newly created task is intially empty and presented as ''someone doing something''.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]

Define a task by * naming it * identifying where it is to be executed * profiling who is to be assigned to it * what goals it directly achieves * and more Note that as little and as much as wanted can be put into a task's definition.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]

Add an '''information need''' to a task by clicking on the ''ADD'' button in the Receives panel. An info need specifies information that agents assigned to the task need to receive to * trigger the task * enable it to succeed (critical) * terminate the task (useful) * improve its execution
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]

Add an ''informatio capability'' to a task by clicking on the ''ADD'' button in the Sends panel. An info capability specifies info agents assigned to a task expect to acquire and be able to share with others.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]

Specify an info need, capability or sharing by * naming the information * listing its elements * indicating whether it is ''pushed'' or ''pulled' * the communication channels to use * timeliness constraints * and more
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]

An information sharing flow connect a tasks that ''produces'' information with a tasks that ''consumes'' it. It is equivalent to connecting an info capability of a task with the info need of another. A sharing flow is created by connecting an info need or a capability to a task. The flow appears in the ''Receives'' of the consuming task and in the ''Sends'' of the producing task.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]

Define an event (always a type, never an actual event) by * renaming it – it was created when first named – * categorizing it with event types * locating where it would happen * stating whether the event can terminate on its own * and more Note that all profile attributes are optional.
All events are listed in '''All events'''
Events can be found by name in the plan's index.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]
Define a phase (always a type) by * renaming it – it was created when first named – * specifying if it is a pre-, co- or post-event phase * and more Note that all profile attributes are optional.
All phases are listed in the plan's '''details'''.
Phases can be found by name in the plan's index.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]

Define an actual or type of organization by * renaming it – it was created when first named – * categorizing it with organization types * If an actual organization, by ** naming the parent organization ** listing the agents it employs ** listing sharing agreements with other organizations * and more Note that all profile attributes are optional.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]
Define a role (always a type) by * renaming it – it was created when first named – * categorizing it * and more Note that all profile attributes are optional.
Roles can be found by name in the plan's index.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]

Define an actual or type of agent by * renaming it – it was created when first named – * categorizing it with agent types * If an actual agent, by ** declaring it a person or system ** setting clearances, languages, availability ** setting constraints on users participating as this agent * and more Note that all profile attributes are optional.
Agents can be found in the plan's ''who's who''.
Agents can also be found by name in the plan's index.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]

Define an actual or type of place by * renaming it – it was created when first named – * categorizing it with place types (such as 'city', 'building' etc.) * if an actual place, by ** naming what place it is within ** giving a street address and postal code ** identifying its geographical area * if a type of place, by ** setting the place (type or actual) it must be in ** the place it must contain * and more Note that all profile attributes are optional.
Places can be found by name in the plan's index.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]

Define a transmission medium (always a type) by * renaming it – it was created when first named – * categorizing it * stating whether it is unicast, multicast or broadcast * naming the other media this one can delegate to * naming its level of security * giving the pattern the media's ''addresses'' must conform to * and more Note that all profile attributes are optional.
Transmission media can be found by name in the plan's index.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]
An obvious way of improving a plan is to resolve issues detected by Channels or by planners. The 'All issues" table aggregates all individual issues found in a plan.
Metrics on all issues found in a plan provides a sense of the current quality of the plan.
If the resolution of an issue is not self-evident and requires input from stakeholders, a survey (with questionnaire) can be created about resolving the issue.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]
When too many tasks are added to a segment, the segment becomes difficult to manage. To shrink a bloated segment, a new segment is usually created and tasks are moved to it.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]

Information sharing protocols (aka procedures or guidelines) are computed by assigning agents to tasks and by deriving information sharing commitments from the flows connecting assigned tasks.
A key concern is making sure that the right agents get assigned to the right tasks, and that only the right agents that are assigned to the tasks on each side of a flow become parties to sharing commitments.
Which agents are assigned to a task is determined by * how a task specifies the agents assignable to it * what agents are in the plan's environments and how they are profiled * how the agents are employed (role, jurisdiction, organization) * how the taxonomies of role, agent, organization etc. are defined

Exactly what sharing commitments are generated for a flow depends on * what agents are assigned to the producing task and consuming task connected by the flow * what restrictions are put on pairing agents into commitments (the committer and beneficiary must be in the same organization etc.) * whether an overriding flow prohibits a pairing of agents
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]

Roles, agents, organizations, places, events etc. (entities) can be categorized. Agents are categorized by agent types, organization by organization types, events by other events (events are always types) etc.
How entities are categorized largely determine the meaning of the tasks, flows, employments etc. that are defined in terms of these entities.
The meaning of a plan boils down to the task assignments and consequent sharing commitments (protocols) that are implied by the plan. Even a small change to the taxonomy (a.k.a. typology) or roles, for example, can cause widespread changes to the protocols computed from a plan and thus its meaning.
Taxonomies are defined implictly by categorizing individual entities. Taxonomies can be visualized to verify that they are correct.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]

The ''flow map'', which is central to the plan editor, shows tasks connected by flows where each flow can imply a potentially large number of sharing commitments.
The ''assignments and commitments map'' makes it easy to see if the sharing commitments generated from the plan are the intended ones.
The map is focused on one agent or one organization (as an aggregate of agents). It shows the commitments that involved that egent or organizations.
The other parties to the commitments can be aggregated by role, organization type or not at all.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]

Planners can enlist the help of stakeholders via surveys. A survey is a questionnaire about elements of the plan or the plan as a whole.
Planners compose questionnaires by adding, ordering, editing etc. statements and questions. Questions can be marked as required or optional.
A questionnaire applies to the plan as a whole or to one kind of plan element (plan questionnaire, task questionnaires, event questionnaires etc.)
Questionnaires can be activated and deactivated. They can be extended while they are being used in surveys.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]
A survey is launched on the plan or on a plan element by applying a questionnaire to it.

script.action: View launched and launch-able surveys on a task

step.description: Once a survey is launched, it can be managed by * inviting users to participate * looking at the answers from survey participants * deactivating or reactivating the survey * editing the survey's questionnaire
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]

Surveys can be launched on an issue that was detected. The questionnaire is automatically generated based on the remediation options.
The questionnaire can be modified and extended while the survey is ongoing.
An issue remediation survey is automatically deactivated when the issue disappears.
Note that the issue remediation questionnaires are by default not shown in the list of all questionnaires; a checkbox must be checked to see them.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]

Once a survey is launched, users can be invited to a survey. Users can be given a deadline to answer the required questions in the survey. After the deadline has passed, the survey is considered late. Late participants can be ''nagged'' (nags are sent by email).
A participant can *accept the invitation by answering questions, *decline the invitation *forward the survey to others (if planners marked the survey as forwardable).
Note that anyone who is forwarded a survey and who is not yet a user of Channels is automatically given a login, password and limited access to the plan as a participant.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]

activity.name: Lookup the results of a survey

step.description:
As participants in a survey answer the questionnaire, results are compiled and made available to the planners.
Results can be viewed by opening the survey and selecting the ''results'' tabs.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]

Users can ask questions, report problems and make suggestions via a feedback widget that appears in their home page, their protocols etc.
Planners can see this feedback and reply to it. The user can then reply back etc. or mark the question, problem or suggestion as resolved.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]

Every element of a plan that has a name can be found from the index.
The index can be filtered by kind of element (role, agent, event etc.), by tags, and by partial name.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]

Every employement of every agent is aggregated in the ''who's who'' table.
The table can be indexed by the name of the agent or by attributes of employment (organization, role, location of employer).
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]

Documents of various types (policy, reference, picture etc.) can be attached to the plan and any element in it.
A table with all documents attached in the plan can be found in the plan's ''bibliography''.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]

The plan and every element in it can be tagged.
The list of all tags used in the plan can be looked up to see what has been marked by any given tag.
For more information, see [${helpUrl}/ch01.html this]

Whenever a plan element is referenced by name in the definition of another, there will also be a link to get to the referenced element's definition.
Also, most forms used to define an element of the plan contain a table listing all and linking to all other elements that reference it in their definitions.
For example, at the bottom of in the profile of a role is an index of all other elements that reference the role or that match the role.
